Thanks for your question, 10083. We are consulting with Dr. Johannes Thrul and will get back to you soon!

Great question 10083 and 10082. Here are my thoughts on the issue of low nicotine cigarettes: I don’t have a comprehensive list of low nicotine cigarettes, so unfortunately you will have to do some research yourselves. Previous studies suggested that there is a risk of what we call “compensatory smoking” with lower nicotine cigarettes – essentially smokers inhaling deeper to taking more puffs in order to get the same amount of nicotine. This, of course, would defeat the purpose of switching to a lower nicotine brand. However, more recent research has shown that this compensatory smoking may not happen for cigarettes really low in nicotine (for more information see this example http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/281392.php). If you decide to switch to a lower nicotine cigarette I encourage you to monitor your smoking behavior really carefully, so you don’t end up smoking more cigarettes or inhale deeper for example. Another alternative would be to gradually reduce the number of cigarettes you smoke of your current brand. Some things you could try there: Pick certain cigarettes you want to eliminate (e.g. the first or last one each day, a cigarette after a meal), you could also think about declaring smoke free zones to get you to smoke less (e.g. stop smoking in your car). Yet another way would be to gradually increase the time interval between cigarettes. What you are willing to try is really up to you – I simply want to give you comprehensive information so you can make an informed decision.

What are your reasons for smoking? Try this SHORT self-test (Don’t worry it’s easy)STOP when you get your score and post it here!https://ucsf.co1.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_73dz87ACkEB28vP#TDII

I've got to run. If you want to try the test sometime, this is what the results mean: A high score in Stimulation suggests that you are a smoker who is stimulated by the cigarette — you feel that it helps wake you, organize your thoughts, and keep you going.A high score in Handling suggests that you feel satisfied by handling cigarettes.A high score in Pleasure Relaxation suggests that using cigarettes makes you feel good.A high score in Crutch: Tension Reduction suggests you use cigarettes as a crutch in moments of stress or discomfort.A high score in Craving: Psychological Addiction suggests you are psychologically addicted to cigarettes. Quitting smoking is difficult for the person who is psychologically addicted.A high score in Habit suggests that you no longer getting much satisfaction from cigarettes.

data.message: Hello group members, we realized that post #43 failed to be shared on Friday, March 6, 2015, so we're posting it now. This missed post only changes our program slightly: our group will now run for 91 days instead of 90, and the weekly tally of comments will happen every Saturday instead of Friday. We apologize for any confusion, and please let us know if you have any questions or concerns. Thanks! :)

Watching this ad, I don't really know how to feel. I guess I have to be honest and say it makes me feel indifferent... I can feel the hurt and pain that she's feeling but it just isn't enough. #17: All change has pros and cons. What are some of the cons of quitting smoking? Why might it be hard for you to quit? #beingconscious

I like to consider myself a social smoker so one of the cons I think of quitting would be being left out of the smoking social situations. Being at parties, etc. most people make a public announcement of them going to smoke and ask people to join them. I always described it as a "quiet time". You can escape loud music and go outside and actually talk to someone. Engage in a real conversation. I noticed the last time I quit, I was in college at a party, and I wasn't outside with the smokers crew. I missed having to go outside to be in nature (no matter what the weather conditions were like) just to smoke a joe. And I'd always have a partner with me, we'd talk about real stuff. Humph.

Anyways, I got in a pretty bad wreck early yesterday morning. We're all extremely lucky to be alive. I didn't make it out unscathed but I'm still very blessed. So I decided to quit smoking. It's been about 34 hours and I've been outside twice with my boyfriend while he smoked. I have no desire whatsoever. So send over those saliva tests! I'm ready to initiate positive changes in my day-to-day life!
A lot of my friends smoke, so I'd miss going out for a smoke with them. And it's also a way to relieve stress and relax that I wouldn't have.
My friends smoke and the want is really bad

It's extremely difficult not to smoke a cigarette when I see someone else smoking but it's gotten easier lately, I havent quit but my control has gotten better. I think this group helps a lot, having the daily reminder. The pros would be the ability to run upstairs much easier though
Breathing easier

10083, we're so sorry to hear that, but glad that you are ok and have been smoke-free for 34 hours.Sounds like for most of you, the desire to smoke is triggered by social situations. It is definitely hard to resist smoking when others around you are doing it. So if you decide to quit, we highly encourage you to tell your friends so they can help minimize your urge to smoke.

I also just downloaded a cool app that tracks how long I've been without a cigarette down to the second. 2 days and 9 hours! It also gives cool facts on how much money youve saved, how many cigarettes you've avoided smoking, the latest benefits and even how many mgs of chemicals you're without. I've also been without approx. 500 mgs of tar since my last one!

Even if you haven't quit, I'd suggest everyone to download it. It can still serve a purpose. "Look at what would've happened if I quit smoking for this long now..." Positive reinforcement is everything!
What's the app called?
10083, we are also interested in which app this is. If you don't mind sharing, tell us the name! :)
Oh I never saw your question, 10067 it's called "Quit it" its a free app on the Apple App Store. Here's a picture of the app icon.
Thank you!
No problem. 6 days and 12 hours smoke free!
Awesome, thank to u
You*

#21: Flavored cigarettes have been outlawed for years now, yet e-cig companies are using old tricks to gain new customers while they still can. Would you have started smoking at an earlier age if the product you used was flavored like your favorite candy? #ecig

No. I did start out smoking menthol though and then switched to nonmenthol. Cigarillos have been flavored forever, I know nobody smokes those. But even when I roll a blunt, I prefer natural flavor. When I used an ecig, I didn't et crazy with all the flavors either. Kept it real light. I like the way cigarettes naturally taste.
I might have, since when I was younger the taste really turned me off.
Even when I've had an e-cig I used tobacco flavors, and have never been a fan of menthol
I like the taste of cigs but I like to use natural or sometimes use a melon or a cherry zig zag
I would have
Thank you for sharing!
#19: Who’s that one friend you can count on to listen to you when you need it? Who will you be able to trust as your supporter when you are ready to quit smoking? #support
A lot of people support me but my sister is my #1

mm, this is a good question. honestly though, it would have to be the person i see in the mirror. there is a lot of support in my life, but if i can't rely on myself in the end... i can't really rely on anyone else either. trust comes from within.
My best friend, definitely.
My brother
My dad
Glad to hear about all your supporters!
What would you miss most if you quit smoking for good? #TDII
Mixing tobacco with marijuana and rolling up a splifff
Having to bare the weather no matter the condition just to smoke. I loved feeling the hot, the cold, the rainy, the windy, etc.
Thanks for sharing guys. I am curious: And what are the things you would be happy to get rid of?
Short breath for sure
Smelling like an ashtray. That's the best one of all! And the discoloration of my teeth! Im gonna save more money now too.
10083, I know you have quit already and that's great to hear. 10067, you really don't like the immediate health effects of smoking. How do you feel about smoking and quitting at the moment?
Ok guys, I've got to run - see you next week!

#20: Part of the new Tobacco Legislation is that physicians and clinicians must encourage and help their smoking patients quit. Do you think help from a health professional would motivate you to quit? #smokingaffectsall
Absolutley . Coming  from a doctor just makes it more meaningful
I'd think so. They're knowledgeable about health and I always feel pressured to take a doctor's advice. They could also probably provide some resources.

Yeah my doctor always asks me about my smoking and whether or not I've quit yet. He's helpful in providing the facts and has offered advice on ways to quit. He'll be so happy to know I'm donzo. It's been 4 days and 10.5 hours!
I already know the benefits of quitting, people that I have no relationship other than professional have absolutely no say in my life decisions

Oh but to answer, no... He never helped me quit. Like I said yesterday, I'm the only one who can decide that for myself AND support myself. Anybody else I allow to support me is on me too. It's my choice and my choice only.
Yes because they can help you quit by giving u a prescription to something that will help
They can't give you a prescription. Using drugs to stop doing drugs is completely counterproductive to your cause.
Couldn't have said it better myself

data.message: #18: Now that you’ve made your list of cons for quitting smoking, let’s consider your top reason not to quit. Post your #1 Con for quitting here and tell us why it’s your biggest concern. You can finish this sentence: "I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that ________." #beingconscious
I won't succeed and fail
10065 got it it spot on,with how many triggers and opportunities there are to smoke its one of if not the hardest addiction to quit
I agree my biggest thing is that I will just end up smoking again no matter what. It extremely hard to quit cold turkey.

I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that all of my friends won't support me. But that doesn't matter to me more than my personal well-being. I really don't know how to answer any of these posts anymore.
I'm worried that I won't be able to cope with my stress and will end up failing. It's a big demotivator since I have tried quitting almost five times.
Happy Monday, group members! Just so you know, your comments are tallied each Friday. Please feel free to message us each week to see how much you've earned!
#10: Educate yourself on the smoking rates and laws in your state. Search up “smoking information” and “smoking bans” in your state. Did any of the information surprise you? #smokingaffectsall
I wasn't to suprized for my state
I was surprised that there were bans within 20 ft of entrances to public places. I feel like I see people smoking right outside of places all the time.

"It is unlawful in Florida for any person under 18 years of age to smoke tobacco in, on, or within 1,000 feet of the real property comprising a public or private elementary, middle, or secondary school between the hours of 6 a.m. and midnight." I learned that I'm a criminal

Love this. Actually, the city of New Orleans just passed a new smoking ban at bars and other establishments. It'll start in April. Now, other cities across Louisiana are looking to pass smoking bans as well.
Same in Kansas
Thank you for looking into this! :)
#13: Do you know anyone who has died from a tobacco-related disease? How did their death affect your own smoking? Post and share your experiences. #reflection
My uncle died from heart failure because he smoked and drank too much.made me stop smoking for a few weeks
My grandma died from smoking related illness but I wasn't smoking at the time

My boyfriend's grandmother died at a really young age (mid 30s) due to lung cancer. He never even met her... But it affects me because his mom is always telling us that we're gonna end up like her mom. It makes me feel really bad, actually. I usually say nothing when she nags us about smoking...
Thinking about this gave me the chills... But it sucks to say that it makes me want a smoke right now. Sorry, just being honest
My one uncle who smokes a lot has heart problems, which makes me want to quit more.
No I don't know anyone but I seen what it does to people
Thank you so much for sharing.

#16: Quitting can help preserve our planet! Without cigarette smoke, the chances of household fires decrease and less secondhand smoke is released into the air we breathe. Can you think of any other environmental improvements that might result from less smoke? Share them here. #beingconscious
Not as many cigarette butts will be littered.
Less pollutants in general will be released into the air.
Not as much litter
There would be a decline in littering because there will be no butts or ciggerete packs just tossed into mother nature
Less litter and less animals likely to eat butts

#15: What strategy do you plan to use when you do decide to quit smoking? Will you use any nicotine replacement therapies (like patch or gum)? Medication? Cold turkey? Counseling? Post and share your plan of action and see if any other group members are on the same page! #beingconscious
cold turkey and with support from close friends
Cold Turkey and help from my brothers
Cold turkey with the support of an everyday, regular exercise program. That always does the trick for me.
Cold turkey with family support
Cold turkey and exercise.
#14: On a scale of 1-10, how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #beingconscious
I need to quit for my family and their health. I'm kinda motivated 6/10
I need to quit because its really bad for my health and I smoke menthol which is really bad
I need to quit for my health,  my loved ones and to save money.
It's extremely important to me. I would say 10/10 but realistically speaking, probably a 7/10.
At this point in time it's about a 6
Did you know that you can avoid almost all of the negative health consequences of smoking if you quit before you are 30 years old? Does that change how you feel about smoking and quitting? #TDII
Are there any studies you can refer me to on this?
Sure - this one for example http://www.cghr.org/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/NEJM-US-Smoking-risks-article.pdf
Thank you!
and this one http://www.bmj.com/content/328/7455/1519
here is a quick overview of health benefits of quitting.
I've got to run - see you next week!

#11: Everyone wants to know whether electronic cigarettes can help smokers quit. Unfortunately, studies are showing that they are not any more effective than a placebo. So health professionals still recommend using well-studied strategies like counseling or nicotine replacement therapies (patch, gum) when you’re ready to quit. #ecig
I think they can help for some people, but they are still as bad as smoking and a lot of people only use them when they can't smoke

I used an ecig to quit before and I used 0 mg of nicotine. I always tell people it's not the nicotine I'm addicted to, rather the act of smoking. So I used an ecig (a lot less than I would use cigarettes) for two weeks straight and then stopped using that too. But I eventually started smoking again, so I'd like to try something different.
That makes sense,  when I used an ecig it was still me doing the act of smoking AND getting nicotine, plus there are bad things for you in ecigs.
Ecigs to me are just something to smoke when I have no cigarettes, and don't help me with cigarette desires at all
E cigs really arent that great any way

#12: Did you know that the number of non-smokers affected by second hand smoke is more than double the number of actual smokers in the U.S.? Who is affected by your second hand smoke?. #smokingaffectsall
I personally try to be considerate of non smokers around me, especially when there's a hild  present
I don't smoke in my car anymore ( due to the film and the chemicals that remain in the car) and I usually only smoke in areas designated for smoking.

I'm always mindful of nonsmokers & often ask people surrounding me in a social situation whether or not they mind... but i know even if it doesn't, it still affects them. most of my friends don't smoke, so going out to bars, night clubs, the casino, restaurants with patio/ courtyard seating are all places i put myself and friends at risk.
I usually go outside and smoke but if im in a social situation and I can't go outside then I ask
I usually go outside and smoke away from people, but my roommate complains about the smell a lot.
Where's the post of the day?
10067, we've decided to change the daily posting time to 12 noon PST. Thanks for noticing!

#9: Remember Drawback #1 ("I don't want to have withdrawal symptoms") from yesterday’s post? Which one of our following comebacks worka for you? #balance• Some withdrawal symptoms are actually signs that my body is healing• I may be coughing more because the cilia (hair-like structures that line my lungs and clean the air I breathe) that were paralyzed by the cigarette smoke are starting to work again, which makes me temporarily cough more• I may have tingling in my arms and legs because my circulation is improving
Then those are really good signs then
They all work for me but I didn't know the tingly sensation was because I was getting circulation back, thatsgood to know
I think the withdrawal being signs that my body is healing works best. I didn't know cigarettes paralyzed cilia.
The last one.
Definitely number one, that statement in itself is just reiterated in the other comebacks. Very interesting and new information! Thanks.

Thanks for your participation during our first week! This week's comments have just been tallied. Feel free to message us to see if you earned $7 this week. Remember, you need to comment on ALL 7 posts to earn money!

#8: Research shows that emphasizing the benefits of quitting over the drawbacks helps smokers quit their habit for good. So try your hand at making a negative a positive and tell us, what's your comeback for this drawback? #balance
You eventually won't have to deal with nicotine cravings all day.
I'll be able to go though stressful situations without wanting nicotine
I don't need the nicotine
Even though I rely on cigarettes to lift my mood on occasion or treat anxiety, I will feel less anxious as a non smoker... Essentially becoming a happier "me".
I wouldn't have nicotine fits anymore

#7: Here are some things to help you maintain your awesome physique when you stop smoking. Which one seems the most helpful? #balance • Make sure you have a well-balanced diet• Chew sugarless gum when you want something sweet• Eat slowly• Plan healthy, low-fat and low-calorie snacks into your day• Watch portion sizes• Read food labels
I think planning healthy snacks would help because it would reduce the urge to eat a lot of junk food.
Snacking all day or reggulwrlu csn actually be brnifitial to your health

I like the idea of chewing sugarless gum when I want something sweet, I get a lot of late night sweet cravings so this'll help. Very recently, I began to eat much slower than usual making sure I chew my food thoroughly too. That's also an easy one to incorporate into your plan.
Are milk and dairy products all that good for you? I hear it's actually really, really bad for you. My family and I have been trying to cut down on the dairy intake as of late.
I've also been practicing chewing thoroughly the last few weeks and it makes a big difference with how much I need to eat
It really does! Something so simple.
I think its a good idea to plan healthy foods because u always gotta watch what u eat
Hi everyone and welcome to TSP! I am available for the next hour. Let me know if you have any questions!

I've got to run guys. One question that came up today was if there are any ways to get free nicotine replacement products to help with quitting. Many of the state quitlines actually provide nicotine replacement like the patch or gum for free. You can just google your state and "quitline" and see what comes up. See you next week and feel free to reach out if anything comes up in the meantime.

#6: Weight gain is one of the top concerns for almost every smoker. We’ve made a list of some tips that can help keep your weight on track while you quit. Pick the one sounds good to you. How could you implement it into your life? #balance • Go for a walk, swim, bike ride or any exercise you enjoy• Find small ways to be more active, like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or parking a little farther away• Find alternatives to snacking, like calling a friend• Drink some extra water
All of them. As long as you stay on your routine it shouldn't be long before you are all done with cigarettes
When I crave a cigarette, I could go on a run instead of smoking or snacking.
Snacking is a problem that I have so doing something social and outdoors could prevent me from munchin'.
I choose all
Aside from smoking cigarettes I actually live an extremely healthy lifestyle including running, drinking a lot if water and tea and working out
#5: What would be the best-case scenario if you quit smoking? #balance
I'd be healthier,
I'd have a realistic fitness program I can follow. I wouldn't have any form of withdrawal symptoms like weight gain or getting sick and finally, my teeth would go back to being super white.
I'd be healthy, I wouldn't be stressed out from withdrawal symptoms and I'd have a little more money in my pocket.
I'd be able to run more than a mile again and would save a lot of money
Yes, yes. So easy to forget about the money I'd be saving!
I'll be able to save alot of money and be more healthier
Better health and more money in my pocket

data.message: #4: Many e-cig companies are actually owned by BIG TOBACCO companies. What do you think their motives are? To have you remain a loyal customer? To help you quit smoking? Other ideas? #ecig
I think they are just giving us the illusion of choice because they know so many people are trying to quit smoking and still want to make money off of us somehow
I think they're trying to make it seem "healthier" so they continue to get money.
I think they are just trying to make more money off us cuz some e cigs u have to buy the liquid and it can be expensive
I think some have an local aspect but most are owned by  big tobacco and encourage the usage because they no longer can make TV commercials for their actual cigarettes.

#3: For any of you who aren’t sure what an e-cig is, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulation. If you were a minor, do you think an e-cig would be more appealing and “safer” to try than a traditional cigarette? #beingconscious http://buff.ly/1JvyHkU

I actually tried them before BECAUSE I thought they were safer since there wasn't any tobacco. I figured I was just getting nicotine. Also the flavors were super appealing to me and my friends in high school.

Down in New Orleans, vapes and mods have become all the rave so as a minor I would've probably fell victim to them due to the buzz. Not to mention how cool these gadgets look and all the crazy flavor combinations you can get... Very appealing indeed. Most people I know that vape have never even tried a traditional cigarette so they use 0 mg of nicotine too. So yes, I would've thought it to be a safer alternative as well.
No some were found to contain antifreeze. Which will kill you a bit slower than real cigarettes but in the end you still die.
I know many minors and young adults who feel like they are 100% safer with e-cigarettes and will scold me for smoking cigs as they're hitting an e-cig
It might seem like their better but it still has toxins maybe not as many has a regular one but stillccauseslong term health problems
Yeah I heard they are just as bad
Don't mean to burst anybody's bubble but let's try to remember to answer the questions at hand... Wouldn't want anybody to miss their bonus bc they didn't actually answer what's being asked ^.^

Hey guys,  Thanks for all the discussion about e-cigs.  I wanted to clarify that any and all commenting and conversation is welcome in these posts.  We are always open to hearing about what is important to those of you who are thinking about quitting and encourage any conversation that advocates for a healthier lifestyle.  The last thing we want to do is limit you guys!
#1: Share a success that you have had in the past. It can be anything from any time. Why did it work? Who helped you? #motivation
I scored the winning run on my baseball team in 5th grade with my dad as the coach
I got into my top choice college. It worked cause I got good grades, and a couple of my teachers proofread my admissions essay.

I successfully ran my first half marathon with under 2 months of training. Why did it work? Because it's something I really wanted. And one of my amazing friends ran by my side every step of the way. When practicing  and even on race day, never left my side. He always always always gave me the motivation I needed when I thought about throwing in the towel.
My family encouraged me to find a job and helped me succeed
Amazing successes! :)
Rebuilding my truck with very little experience and doing it all corectly
#2: How would you support someone who tells you they want to quit smoking? #motivation
Refuse to offer them a cigarette or give them one if they ask and encourage them to keep away from them
I wouldn't smoke in front of them and would invite them to try something stress relieving with me, like going on a run.

Discussing the pros and con's with them and letting them make the decision themselves. And help them with the decision they make if they decide to quit help them with a better diet and more active lifestyle to get the lungs repaired and help them to stay on track
Not smoke around them and when they want one tell them its better they dont
I would suggest tips for starting a diet/ detox and encourage them to incorporate an exercise or fitness program into their daily regimen.
Encourage them they don't need that bad habit in there life and help them get through it by doing things they like to do that will help them keep there mind off of it
Just try to help them be there for them and not let temptation come around
Offer them someone to quit with.
These are great ways to show your support. Thanks for sharing!

data.message: I met someone yesterday who smoked a pack of full flavor cigarettes every day for 22 years. She says after she quit she started to cough up tar... In place of what would normally be phlegm. Is this true and why is this? Also, another one of my friends quit cold turkey and got a severe cold. His doctor recommended that he slowly try to ween off them to prevent the withdrawal symptoms, I hope to quit cold turkey so what can I do to avoid this maybe? I do not smoke as often or for as long as he did either.

Hi 10083, good questions! First, it is pretty normal that the lung wants to get rid of all the toxins and tar after quitting, so some initial cough etc. is nothing out of the ordinary. This will get better after some time though (depending on how much the persons smoked). To answer you second question, withdrawal is a common concern of many smokers who are thinking about quitting. Nicotine replacement products can initially help to avoid withdrawal and slowly ween you off the nicotine - so this may be something to consider. How much do you currently smoke?

Through the week I can go through only a single pack, although when the weekend rolls around and I'm in social situations that involve drinking... I can pretty much smoke a pack in an entire night. But won't smoke the next day at all, makes me feel horrible (obviously). I don't think I have a problem with nicotine... I quit smoking cigarettes in the summer or '13 using a vape mod for less than 2 weeks with 0 mg of nicotine. I don't want to quit using any replacement products as I am actually against even taking medication to cure a simple headache. But I've been smoking year round since fall of '13. This is the longest period of constant smoking I've done & I haven't been exercising regularly since either. So these are new concerns I have for when I Hope to quit sometime this year.
Is there a way to receive free quit smoking aids such as nicorette or chantix?
Great question, 10082. There may be a way - a lot of the state telephone quit lines offer free nicotine replacement therapy. Let me check that for you. Which state do you live in?
Montana

Great - I just checked: There is a way to receive free nicotine replacement products through the quitline and other medication at reduced costs. Check this link: http://dphhs.mt.gov/publichealth/mtupp/quitline
Do you think you will give them a call 10082?
Yes.
Great 10082! How much of a priority is quitting for you at the moment?
6out of 10
Cool 10082! I am curious: Why is it a 6 and not a 0 for example?
I have a want to quit but at the same time I enjoy smoking and would have a very difficult time giving it up.

data.story: Johannes Thrul updated the event photo in The Doctor Is In.
Johannes Thrul created a private event.

data.message: Does using rolling tobacco have any difference in health versus commercial cigarettes?

Hi 10067 - unfortunately I don't know of any studies that compared roll your own with pre-rolled cigarettes. I would not expect a difference with regards to health effects though, since essentially both options are combustion of tobacco which is the main factor for the adverse health effects. Does this answer your question?
Yes thank you, wishful thinking

I'm no doc but im gonna say rolling your own is worse. The filter (if the user even rolls one in) is way smaller than that of a normal cigarette. But I guess it may also depend on how you're rolling. I know people who roll teeny tiny, Virginia slim-like cigarettes and people who roll big fat ones. Less would be better? But that filter still gets me, idk. And they're so much cheaper. I think that's a bad thing too.

Ou, another question! So I hit my head really hard in the wreck and have had headaches on and off since then. Right now, I know for sure I'm experiencing a sinus headache. I've linked most of my headaches to my head injury... But my boyfriends mom says I probably have headaches cos I quit smoking too. Now, is there anything I can do to prevent those headaches? It's only been 4.5 days so I have no idea what kind of withdrawal symptoms are to come as well.

yes, headaches can be a withdrawal symptom as well. One thing to do about that to consider would be to use nicotine replacement. But if you are feeling fine otherwise and can deal with your cravings that may not be necessary. Let me say one thing though: the good news about withdrawal symptoms is that they get better the longer you go without any smoking. So after about 2 weeks you can expect the physical withdrawal to be over. So just hang in there, use a painkiller if nothing else helps. Here are some more tips. Anything useful?

I know I've got 15 minutes till you're in, but I'm gonna go ahead and ask my question. I quit smoking 4 days and 15 hours ago. I recently started running again to train myself for the upcoming races in New Orleans. I've got a 10k come April. But I got in a wreck over the weekend and had what I would consider moderate TBI and I've had swelling and a lot of bruising to my knee and thighs. So running is out of the question for now... But what else can I do to prevent the weight gain to come? Idk how well dieting is gonna work for me either.
I'm not the doctor but I'd say calisthenic exercise is a good option

Good question 10083: Great job - it's great to hear that you quit - keep up the good work! And sorry to hear about your knee and I hope you get better soon! There are a couple of things I can recommend: First off you may consider taking it more slowly with your exercise like starting with quick walking first, before you run, to five your muscles and joints a couple of weeks to adjust. You may also want to consider other kinds of exercise that are less stressful on your joints - like swimming or cycling for example. With regards to food, there are plenty of options for healthy food choices. Here are some ideas. Do you think some of this is going to work for you?

I always always read labels. But the last point is gonna help most. Not depriving myself of the food I love, but making it work in my favor by balancing it out with lighter portions for the rest of the day. I'll try walking till I can pick up running again. Thanks.

Sure - happy to help. And yes it's all about being flexible with regard to your food choices. You may also want to consider sugarfree gum, or healthy snacks like vegetable sticks throughout the day to help with the oral fixation and stimulation that cigarettes used to provide. Toothpicks to chew on can work great as well.
That's a good idea. The lady I was telling you about who quit after 20 years told me she keeps candy cigarettes on her now and takes one out the pack and eats it whenever she has a craving. Lol.
Haha that's something I haven't heard before :) Whatever works I guess!

data.message: Are there any studies showing how psychedelics can help with cigarette addiction and cravings?

Great question: There is some recent research that suggests "magic mushrooms" may be effective as an adjunct to a behavioral smoking cessation intervention. This is not to suggest that people should just randomly start using them, since this study carefully administered them in the context of a treatment program. But, yeah they may be very effective to treat addictive behaviors. Here is a reference, if you are interested: http://hub.jhu.edu/2014/09/11/magic-mushrooms-smoking
Thank you! And good point, self medicating on mushrooms is generally more dangerous(for lack of a better word)than with a professional
